chapters.title: Introduction
content: Welcome to the CV Project - a beginner-level project designed to help you learn the basics of web development. In this project, you will create a simple online resume or CV using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. This project will teach you how to structure your content using HTML, style your content using CSS, and add interactivity to your page using JavaScript. By the end of this project, you'll have a beautiful and functional online resume that you can use to showcase your skills and experience to potential employers.
By the end of the CV Project, you will have gained the following skills:
- HTML: You will learn how to structure your content using HTML tags and create headings, paragraphs, lists, and links.
- CSS: You will learn how to style your content using CSS, including how to change font styles and colors and how the box model works.
- JavaScript: You will learn how to query the HTML elements and make your resume organized.
By completing this project, you will learn the following skills:
- Version Control with Git (if you decide to use it to manage your code)
So what are you waiting for? Let's get started and build your first online resume!

chapters.title: a. Basics
content: There are many different HTML tags, each with its own specific purpose. Some common HTML tags include:
- `<h1>`, `<h2>`, `<h3>`, etc.: These tags are used to define headings of different levels, with `<h1>` being the largest and `<h6>` being the smallest.

- `

`: This tag is used to define paragraphs of text.
- `<a>`: This tag is used to create hyperlinks to other web pages or resources.
- ``: This tag is used to insert images into a web page.
- `<div>`: This tag is used to group together other HTML elements and apply styles to them.
- `<span>`: This tag is similar to the `<div>` tag, but is used to apply styles to smaller sections of text.
Create a h1 title with you name.

chapters.title: b. paragraph and list: self-introduction & bullet points skills
content: ## paragraph and list: self-introduction & bullet points skills
Great! Now, let's list out your skills. Use `ul` and `li` tags to create an unordered list, and include HTML, CSS, and JavaScript as list items.
